Governing_Law: Rules governing discovery and prior case law
Evidence_Assessment: Relevance and timing of discovery questions
Decision_Outcome: Defendant not required to answer post-1990 market research or patent validity questions; follow-up questions on prior art and sales allowed
Burden_of_Proof: Plaintiff bears burden to show relevance of discovery requests
Legal_Rule: Relevant discovery questions must advance a party's case or damage the opponent's; irrelevant or expert opinion-seeking questions are disallowed
Outcome_on_Merits: Not reached; decision limited to discovery disputes
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Court applied discovery rules fairly based on relevance and timing
Key_Evidence_Considered: Market research (post-1990), prior art, sales data, patent validity inquiries
Legal_Framework: Federal rules of civil procedure regarding discovery
Applicant_Challenge: Plaintiff's attempt to compel answers to broad discovery questions
Court_Result: Limited grant of oral discovery; costs awarded proportionally
Legal_Rule_Source: Prior case law and procedural rules
Defendant_Response: Refused to answer certain discovery questions as irrelevant
Remedy_Requested: Compel defendant to answer discovery questions
Outcome: Partially granted: follow-up questions allowed, others denied
Authority: Court with jurisdiction over patent disputes
Jurisdiction: Federal court (implied by patent subject matter)
Governing_Rule: Relevance and timing standards for discovery
